title: Two Rivers Way Walking Route

images.title: FollowMeChaps / Millennium Bridge, Congresbury
images.caption: Millennium Bridge, Congresbury at the start of the walk. This pedestrian bridge which spans the river Yeo links the main part of the village to the Congresbury Millennium Green. The bridge and green formed part of the village's marking of the year 2000 celebrations.

images.title: Jonathan Billinger / Two Rivers Way, west of Stanton Drew
images.caption: West of Stanton Drew. This path links the Avon at Keynsham to the Yeo at Congresbury making a pleasant walk across North Somerset countryside. The B&B on the left is well placed!

images.title: Derek Harper / Approaching Woollard
images.caption: Approaching Woollard. On the Two Rivers Way, heading up the Chew valley. The new bridge can just be seen on the left.

images.title: Derek Harper / Two Rivers Way passing Chew Court
images.caption: Passing Chew Court in Chew Magna. The Way follows a footpath along the east side of the grounds of the court, which is "said to have been one of the country residences of the Bishops of Bath and Wells" and is of "C14/C15 origin"

images.title: Colin S Pearson / ST570615 northern-most edge of Chew Valley Lake
images.caption: Northern-most edge of Chew Valley Lake

images.title: Jonathan Billinger / Stanton Drew standing stones
images.caption: Stanton Drew standing stones

images.title: Dr Duncan Pepper / Pensford Viaduct
images.caption: Pensford Viaduct This railway viaduct at Pensford makes a theatrical entrance for the footpath to the Chew Valley and the Stone Circles at Stanton Drew.

description: Starting on Congresbury Bridge over the River Yeo follow the Two Rivers Way through Somerset to Keynsham on the River Avon. The walk passes through Wrington, Chew Stoke, Chew Magna, Compton Dando and Pensford with sections along the River Yeo and River Chew to enjoy. Other highlights on the route include the Stanton Drew Stones which include the Great Circle - the second largest stone circle in Britain (after Avebury Stones ). You'll also pass the lovely Chew Valley Lake which has delightful nature trails and a variety of wildlife. Near here there's also the photogenic Pensford Viaduct which is a Grade II listed building, spanning the River Chew near the attractive village of the same name. All the way there's splendid views of the Mendip Hills AONB and the Somerset countryside.
